text: Clear dark amber color with a short, lasting beige head. Sweet sugary nose. Toffee sweetness with some burnt malts, raisins and ripe fruit. Lots of lively carbonation on the tongue. Sweet malty beer

Flying Bison makes some damn decent lager beers. This one is a brilliant chestnut brown, perfectly clear with a small head of fine bubbles. Its nose has bit of caramel and a nice floral note to round out out. This is a nice, malty beer but still relatively dry and drinkable. There is just a hair of sweetness to bring out some chocolate to go with the otherwise toasty, bready malt character. This is a full bodied brew but the carbonation is vigorous enough to cut through and keep it from feeling too heavy. It finishes with some lingering raisin sweetness and a touch of bitterness. Nobody cares about German styles anymore but if they did this brewery would be got shit.

Transfer from BA review on 12-23-13-

 Poured from bottle into a pint glass

 Appearance  The beer pours a mahogany color to ruby-brownish color with a one finger of mocha colored head. The head has a decent level of retention leaving a nice level of streaky lace on the sides of the glass once it fades.

 Smell  The aroma of the beer is heaviest of sweeter smells of toffee and caramel with some lighter sweet smells of a dark fruit nature of raisin and cherry mixed within. Other aromas of a more toasted malt smell as well as a bit of a roasted brown bread smell are there as well. 

 Taste  The taste begins with a roasted malt taste combined with tons of caramel and toffee sweetness. The roasted malt gets a little bit more toasted as the flavor advances, with the sweet flavors growing more intense as some darker fruit flavors also join the tongue. At the same time a little bit of a nutty flavor joins the tongue, maintaining a rather light presence to the end of the taste. The caramel and toffee surge again at the end, along with a little bit of cinnamon and nutmeg and some more roasted malt coming to the tongue, to in the end, leave a rather smooth and sweet malty flavor to linger on the tongue.

 Mouthfeel  The body of the beer is on the slightly thicker side with a carbonation level that is on the slightly lower side. For the style, with all the roasted and sweet flavors, the combo of thickness and carbonation are rather nice, and helps create a slower sipper then would traditionally be encountered for a brew of only 6.1 % abv.

 Overall  A rather tasty and sweet malty winter brew. Rather tasty and a nice winter warmer without all the boozy flavors.
Trade from Ron. Thanks! Sweet, malty, caramel nose. Palate is smokey, a bit of gritty depth, more malty notes, with some butterscotch. This is really well done. Complex and enjoyable.

On tap at the Brewery. Poured a nice dark amber with decent head and good lacing. Good nose of chocolate malt and licorice, taste is of toasted malt. Smooth easy drink, malted but not cloying. Good stuff.

A: Dark Brown/light Reddish hue, mild Brown Head, no lacing

S: Dark Roasted Chocolate Malt, mild Nutty and Coffee on back end

T: Dark Chocolate Malt, mild Nuttiness

M: Medicore Carbonation, Medium to Full Bodied, Malty Finish

Overall, I have always been a fan of the Blizzard Bock (aka Hoops) but this years offering seem to lacked in carbonation, which really enhances the flavor.
Chocolate aroma. Pours dark brown. Taste of chocolate and roasted beans. Smooth drinking,. Nice beer.
is a dark red in color, there is a hint of cocoa on the tongue and, slightly bitter yet easy drinking
A dark ruby-red with a white head.  Roasted chocolates with ruby-red fruits, yet not sweet. Good sized body, with a simple linger.
Draft at Coles, Buffalo NY. Darker brown with ruby hues. Chocolate notes, some dried dark fruit, light clove. Pretty flavorful. Decent

UPDATED: APR 11, 2015 Bottle.  Pours a deep mahogany with a frothy brown head.  Head fades pretty quickly.  Definite chocolate-hazelnut vibe to it, with a very creamy mouthfeel.  Good beer for sure, one of the best Ive had from Flying Bison, I think.  Almost a little too sweet, though.
Re-rate: 4/11/15

(bottle - 12 oz) Reddish brown color with a thin tan head. Aroma is lightly sweet with some roasted and smoked malts along with some caramel. Flavor is much the same. Begins with some caramel malts, some smoke, roasted malts, and a light bitter coffee finish. Smooth and sweet. Not bad.

2009-01-24. Dark red brown body is near headless. Flavour has a tangy quality to it, sweetish overall with light bitterness. (6+) Mild aroma, tangy malt, lightly nutty,vague hint at smoke/roast. (6+) Average palate. Meh, okay.  Thanks to Mabel for pointing out I had not entered this! Bottle. Coles Rare Beer Fest, Buffalo.

[1969-20090124] Bottle. Floral grains and weird lake water malt aroma with mild chocolate hints. Clear, dark red body with a quick off-white foamy head. Grainy toasted bread (melba) floral flavour. Medium body. Fair.
(@ Coles; Buffalo, NY)

Bottle (12oz).  Clear deep mahogany pour with a large frothy tan head (4-).  Sweet aroma, roast cereal grain and chocolate, floral and dry.  The taste follows - sweet, but plenty of woody bitterness to even it out, more dry cocoa than in the nose.  Light body, mild carbonation, slight alcohol warmth in the quick finish - sort of a powdery dry chocolate finish.  Nice lighter winter drink.
On tap at brewery. Pours a clear deep brown body with a light tan frothy head. Nice roasted malty sweet aroma. Flavor is very similar with some mocha hints. Good fresh mouthfeel. Good beer.
On tap @ brewery - Pours a light brown color with a small off white head.  Very light lacing.  Aroma and flavor is toasted malt and light esters.  Medium body.  A decent DB.

Bottle. Pours red/brown with a beige head. Light roasted aroma with caramel, coffee, wood, and earth. Medium smooth body. Great malty flavor with roast, earth, tobacco, coffee grounds and burnt wood. Very nice.
Fantastic seasonal from this brewery. Picked up a growler from my local store. Job well done Flying Bison
This is the beast! best flying bison yet. choo choo!!! here comes the good train.

On tap, 8/27/07.  Nice tawny brown color with tan foam, decent lacing too.  Aroma is lots of dark German malts, kinda dusty.  Flavor surprises me, very complex malt bill with lots of richness, good carbonation, just a hint of bitterness in the finish.  A very nice surprise.

Clear, bright mahogany w/ light brown, frothy foam. Sweet, malty (licorice, caramel) aroma w/ some light roasty, earthy notes (burnt roast beef, tobacco). Light feel. Flavour is malty & sweet w/ a mild, earthy hop bitterness.

Deep roasted malt aroma, treacle and molasses, dark copper, with a small tan head. Malty, wheaty taste, with some caramel. Light bodied, well balanced, sweet, has a pleasant mouthfeel. Terrific!

 Thank You rudolf.

Sample at DougShoemakers 2005 December gathering - growler courtesy of rudolf. Dark mahogany colour with a wispy head. Aroma of roasted malt and bitter, nutty cocoa. Flavour of molasses, tobacco, caramel and malt, with a dry, roasty finish. I generally find dunkels to be unexciting beers, but this one really surprised me, and was one of the highlights of the evening.

Growler at December at DougShoemakers 2005 -- courtesy of rudolf. Pours a clear dark ruby-brown with a small light-brown head. Interesting aroma of nuts, chocolate, wood, caramel and roasted malt. Flavours a little mild for me but its very nice: roasted malt, nuts, some wood and a touch of chocolate. Light bodied. Definitely one of the better Dunkels Ive had, well done.
growler. ruby-mahogany coloured body with a small off-white ring of head. aroma is roasty with soft wood notes. nice carbonation - chocolate stickiness and rich earthy malt. flavourful! thanks Rudy.

Growler from Rudolf, Dougs, Christmas 2005.  Wow, the surprise of the evening for sure.  Dark brown, decent tan head.  Aroma of sweet dark malt and pot (Im not kidding, I dont smoke, but have been to enough concerts to smell "Ottos Jacket" - that is what it smelled like).  Taste is very nice - a good dunkel full of sweetness and assertive medium body.  Finishes with some hops.  Maybe not as complex as the Dennisons Dunkel, which is my favourite in this style, but it approaches that level.  What a pleasant surprise, well done guys.

Growler from rudolf. Deep ruby brown color, some ruby highlights, thinner tan head. Nice nose of dry chocolate, earthy malt, a bit woody with a bit of roast. Medium body carries across the earthy, lightly roasted flavor. Light bitterness, cocoa again. A solid tasting beer with quite a bit of drinkability. Very well done Flying Bison.

UPDATED: JAN 26, 2009 Bottle 355ml 
Appearance:  Clear, filtered dark lager. Dark ruby on brown base. Mid plus creamy head. 3+.Nose:  Mid roast feel with sweet malt and mineral hoping , hint of caramel. 7- Flavor/Palate : Medium bodied with thinner finish. Nutty , brown malts, slightly earthy with some of chocolate feel. Fairly standard finish/offering.
Ruby/brown, tan head.  Roasty chocolate dominates with some coffee, cherries - almost stoutlike.  Rich and bitter chocolate, burnt malt.  Lingering dry chocolate finish.  Very nice.
Scotch darker colour with lace in glass. Good nose of chocolate malt and licorice, taste is anise-like. Toasted malt. Smooth easy drink, malted but not cloying. Well done dunkel,Thanks Rudolph.
